abstract.p: One of the main research topics in scientific visualization is to "visualize the appropriate features" of a certain structure or data set. Geodesics are very important in geometry and physics, but there is one major problem which prevents scientists from using them as a visualization tool: The differential equations for geodesics are very complicated and in most cases numerical algorithms must be used. There is always a certain approximation error involved. How can you be sure to visualize the features and not only the approximation quality. We present here an algorithm to overcome this problem. This paper consists of two parts. In the first, a geometric method for the construction of geodesics of arbitrary surfaces is introduced. This method is based on the fundamental property that geodesics are a generalization of straight lines on plains. In the second part these geodesics are used to generate local nets on the surfaces.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: In this paper we will deal with geodesics, which are in some sense the shortest connections on surfaces. They play an important role in differential geometry for the investigation of surfaces, as in physics. In classical mechanics, the geodesic curves can be interpreted as unaccelerated movements. In the general relativity geodesics are the possible world lines of test particles and therefore give a possibility to gauge the space time.

The geodesics are given by nonlinear differential equations, which in general are not easy to solve. We are now pursuing a new idea for the construction of the geodesics on smooth surfaces, by a purely geometric method, which makes us independent of the complexity of the description of the surface or the physical problem.

First, a short introduction to the differential geometry of curves and surfaces, which are the basis when dealing with geodesics, is presented. More details can be found in [?]. Then the geometric method and the algorithm of constructing geodesics is presented. Finally local nets are build with these geodesics. div.head: Geodesics
div.p: Geodesics are to a certain extent a generalization of straight lines, shortest connections in the flat Euclidean space. In the case of curved spaces the shortest connections are no longer straight lines. One can think of a surface on which one stretches a cord between two points and the cord cannot leave the surface. On a sphere for example the geodesics are sections of great circles. So geodesics are curves which have only the curvature, being forced upon them by the surface. Here we should mention that the minimality is a local property, globally however this is not true, because there can be more than one geodesic connecting two points. Conversely shortest connections on simply connected surfaces are always geodesics.

The geodesic curvature is a measure for the change of the angle between the curve and the tangent, by parallel transport along the curve. This means that the normal of a geodetic corresponds to the surface normal. For the curvature of the geodesic we get:

Thus, in a neighborhood of some point, the geodesic to a given direction Û is equal to the normal section in this direction. This allows to construct the geodetic locally by the orthogonal projection relative to the tangent plane ÌÔË on the surface.

In this way the task of computing geodesics on a surface reduces to projection tangents on the surface. The main point is now how to choose the length of the tangents to project to keep the fault small.

div.head: Computational efficiency
div.p: Let's have a look on the computational effort of one step. The computation of the tangent plane means an evaluation of Ù and Ú.

To determine the tangent direction one has only to compute a scalar product and a vector addition. The adaptation of the step length means one or two evaluations of the parameter functions. Thus the main time consuming point is the iteration of the projection algorithm.
The effort of one iteration:

Computation of the new parameter point a simple vector addition Computation of the corresponding surface point evaluation of the parametrization functions Projecting it on the tangent plane simple scalar product and vector addition. Testing in which region the point lies simple scalar products.

Finally the computational effort per step is determined by the number of evaluations of the parameter functions which corresponds to the number of iterations plus maximum two evaluations for the step adaptation.

In general the number of iterations lies between one and ten. In our examples we had an average number of 5.5 iterations per step. This is not much in comparison with the standard fourth order Runge-Kutta method without step adaptation, where one has to compute at least four times the six Christoffel symbols.

div.head: Geodetic Nets
div.p: What about nets of geodesics?

Because the geodesics are very sensitive to local variations of the surface, they are not useful for global nets, but for investigation of local behavior they can be used. We followed two different basic approaches:

div.head: Pseudo-orthogonal nets
div.p: These nets are constructed in the neighborhood of some point of interest. Two emphasized orthogonal geodesics, starting in this point, are constructed. They were used to determine the starting points and directions of two families of geodesics. The starting points we get by separating the two start geodesics in parts of equal arc length. The start directions are orthogonal to these emphasized geodesics. (In this section orthogonal means always orthogonality on the surface, not in the parameter space.) When the geodesics intersect themselves or another geodesic of the same family the construction is interrupted. In the ideal case we get two bundles of orthogonal geodesics (e.g. on a plane or some isometric surface). In general the intersections of the 'orthogonal' families are not orthogonal and it may even happen that they don't intersect at all. That means that we don't get nets in the classical sense, but this wasn't our aim. With these nets it is easy to classify the starting point, and to find the asymptotic directions (directions with Gaussian curvature zero) if they exist.
Here we want to cite the Gauss-Bonnet theorem, which gives a remarkable relation between the topology of a compact surface and the integral of its curvature.
The sum of the interior angles of a geodesic triangle Ì is equal to the integral of the Gaussian curvature Ã over Ì .
This is only a special case, but for our intention it is sufficient.
Important applications for us are:

On an orientable surface of negative or zero curvature, two geodesics ½ and ¾ starting in one point Ô ¾ Ë cannot meat again in another point Õ ¾ Ë, such that they are the boundary of a simple region Ì Ë.
On a surface Ë of negative curvature, homeomorph to a cylinder, then Ë has at most one simple closed geodesic.

This shows that the behavior of geodesics differs very much dependent on the Gaussian curvature, so this method is especially successful in the case of surfaces with negative Gaussian curvature or in the neighborhood of hyperbolic points. On surfaces with strictly positive Gaussian curvature or in the neighborhood of elliptical points, such nets become in cause of self intersections soon chaotic.
